qas.question: In what year did The Times ceased its policy of using courtesy titles for living persons before full names on first reference?
What kind of style is now confined to the "Court and Social" page of The Times when referring to the use of courtesy titles?
When The Times ceased its policy of using courtesy titles, it continued to use them for what kind of name on references after the first?

context: In June <a0_0>1990<a0_0/>, The Times ceased its policy of using courtesy titles ("Mr", "Mrs", or "Miss" prefixes) for living persons before full names on first reference, but it continues to use them before <a2_0>surnames<a2_0/> on subsequent references. The more <a1_0>formal style<a1_0/> is now confined to the "Court and Social" page, though "Ms" is now acceptable in that section, as well as before surnames in news sections.
